title: Klaus Wiegand
text:
Klaus Wiegand (born 16 August 1941) was a <a href="Major%20general">Major general</a> in the <a href="German%20Democratic%20Republic">East German</a> <a href="National%20People%27s%20Army">People's Army</a>. Between 1987 and 1990 he was in charge of "Military District III" of the German Democratic Republic, headquartered in <a href="Leipzig">Leipzig</a>.
Life.
Klaus Wiegand was born during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">war</a> in <a href="Stadtilm">Stadtilm</a>, a very small town some 30 km (20 miles) south of <a href="Erfurt">Erfurt</a> in the southern part of what was then central Germany. His father worked in a shoe factory. Following his school final exams he started an apprenticeship as a <a href="machinist">machinist</a>. By this time his home region had become the <a href="German%20Democratic%20Republic">German Democratic Republic</a>, formally founded in October 1949 from what had previously been the <a href="Soviet%20occupation%20zone">Soviet occupation zone</a> established following May 1945, which had marked Germany's defeat in the war. Wiegand cut short his apprenticeship and on 8 April 1959 joined the young country's recently established <a href="National%20People%27s%20Army">army</a>. He joined a tank regiment and received basic training as a <a href="Gunner%20%28artillery%29">gunner</a> before being transferred to the <a href="Land%20Forces%20of%20the%20National%20People%27s%20Army">Land Forces</a> Officer Academy where he studied from 1959 till 1961. After this, till 1966, he <a href="Zugf%C3%BChrer%20%28military%29">commanded a unit</a> in the . Meanwhile in 1962 he joined East Germany's ruling <a href="Socialist%20Unity%20Party%20of%20Germany">Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED / "Sozialistische Einheitspartei Deutschlands")</a>. Between 1966 and 1971 he served as a Staff Officer for information with the based in <a href="Erfurt">Erfurt</a>. Between 1971 and 1975 he attended the <a href="Combined%20Arms%20Academy%20of%20the%20Armed%20Forces%20of%20the%20Russian%20Federation">"Michail Wassiljewitsch Frunse" Combined Officers' Military Academy (""Михаил Васильевич Фрунзе" Общевойсковая академия Вооруженных Сил Российской Федерации")</a> in Moscow, emerging with a degree in Military Sciences.
After getting back to <a href="East%20Germany">East Germany</a> Wiegand took charge of the <a href="Reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</a> sub-department of his former regiment, before being promoted in 1979 to become head of the <a href="Military%20operation">Operations Department</a>, still with the . There followed a switch in 1979 to a staff position in charge of the Operations Department of "Military District III": the position covered approximately the southernmost third of the German Democratic Republic and was based in <a href="Erfurt">Erfurt</a>. Here he worked with <a href="Major%20general">Major general</a> . Between 1980 and 1982 he was back in Moscow, training at the <a href="Military%20Academy%20of%20the%20General%20Staff%20of%20the%20Armed%20Forces%20of%20Russia">General Staff Academy</a>. On his return he became deputy commander and chief of staff with the , based in <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a>.
From 1 May 1984 till 31 October 1986 he was based in <a href="Halle%20%28Saale%29">Halle</a> where he commanded the . On 1 March 1986, in the batch of promotions created in celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of the <a href="National%20People%27s%20Army">National People's Army</a>, he was promoted to the rank of <a href="Major%20general">Major general</a>. He served for a year as Chief of Staff and Deputy chief of "Military District III" before himself taking charge of District III in succession to . He served in this position between 1987 and 1990, resigning his post a few days before the enactment of <a href="German%20reunification">German reunification</a> on 2 October 1990.
